author: Rebecca Buechel

comments.message: Interesting read for "a day in the life of an ebola clinic" in Sierra Leone http://www.irinnews.org/report/100716/day-in-the-life-of-a-kenema-ebola-treatment-centre
Rebecca, there is also a rumour going around that the drips given in the field hospitals are actually "death drips".  Again all roads lead to community perceptions, fear and trust.

description:
There could be a "with fever" waiting area and a "without fever" one.
In the "with fever" area (as people wait for ebola lab test results), paint personal space waiting areas on the floor so safe distance is respected around patients standing, sitting (on a sterilizable surface ?) or lying down to avoid possible inadvertant touch contact.

This way patients will feel safer while waiting and will pick up the habit of what personal distance to employ.

Site with some examples of floor line markings in warehouses etc~
http://www.riggotts.co.uk/index.php/services/warehouses/
summary: Fear of contaigion may keep patients & HCWs away from healthcare facilities. In reception/triage areas, have appropriate "safe-distance" waiting areas painted (or delineated with colored, sanitizable tape) on the ground to help registering patients maintain safe distance from possibly contaminated ones.
title: Keeping "regular" hospitals functioning during an outbreak
